citeinfo.origin: New Mexico Tech, Department of Chemistry
citeinfo.title: Parallel Factor Analysis (Gabrielsen)
citeinfo.othercit: Cory, R.M., K.M. McKnight, 2005. Fluorescence spectrospcopy reveals ubiquitous prescence of oxidized and reduced quinones in dissolved organic matter. Environmental Science and Technology 39, 8142-8149.

descript.abstract: Between July 2010 and September 2011, samples of dissolved organic carbon were collected from shallow groundwater wells in a meander bend of the East Fork Jemez River in the Valles Caldera National Preserve. These samples were analyzed by fluorescence spectroscopy and modeled using parallel factor analysis (PARAFAC) to identify loadings of fluorophores in excitation-emissionn matrices (EEMs).
descript.purpose: PARAFAC quantifies the relative contributions of fluorophores to the overall fluorescence signature.
descript.supplinf: These data are presented in tabular form and are made available through New Mexico's Experimental Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (NM EPSCoR) data portal. The portal provides access to data generated by and of use to the EPSCoR community including researchers, educators, and policy leaders, as well as the general public.

idinfo.useconst: Users are cautioned that the file contains multiple tabs with inconsistent or missing labels.
